greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Run Length Transform of A000225.
comment: a(n) can be also computed by replacing all consecutive runs of zeros in the binary expansion of n with * (multiplication sign), and then performing that multiplication, still in binary, after which the result is converted into decimal. See the example below.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 0..8192
example: The same result can be also obtained more directly, by realizing that '111' and '11' are the binary representations of 7 and 3, and 7*3 = 21.
Written as an irregular triangle in which row lengths are the terms of A011782:
Right border gives 1 together with the positive terms of A000225.
mathematica: f[n_] := 2^n - 1; Table[Times @@ (f[Length[#]]&) /@ Select[ Split[ IntegerDigits[n, 2]], #[[1]] == 1&], {n, 0, 100}] (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Jul 11 2017 *)
program: (define (A246674 n) (fold-left (lambda (a r) (* a (A000225 r))) 1 (bisect (reverse (binexp->runcount1list n)) (- 1 (modulo n 2)))))
xref: Cf. A003714 (gives the positions of ones).
A001316 is obtained when the same transformation is applied to A000079, the powers of two.
Run Length Transforms of other sequences: A071053, A227349, A246588, A246595, A246596, A246660, A246661, A246685, A247282.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Sep 08 2014
